questions.question_text: A cloud administrator would like to maintain file integrity checks through hashing on a cloud object store. Which of the following is MOST suitable from a performance perspective?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
From a performance perspective, the most suitable hashing algorithm for maintaining file integrity checks on a cloud object store would be MD5 (option C).

MD5 is faster compared to SHA-256 and SHA-512, especially for large files. While SHA-256 and SHA-512 are more secure and resistant to collision attacks compared to MD5, they are also computationally more intensive and thus slower.

AES (option D) is not a hashing algorithm but a symmetric encryption algorithm used for securing data at rest. It's not suitable for file integrity checks through hashing.

Therefore, in terms of performance, MD5 would be the most appropriate choice among the options provided. However, it's important to note that MD5 is considered less secure than SHA-256 and SHA-512, so depending on the level of security required, SHA-256 might be preferred despite its higher computational overhead.

Selected Answer: C
MD5 is generally faster than SHA-512 when it comes to hashing speed. This is because MD5 produces a shorter hash (128 bits) compared to SHA-512 (which produces a 512-bit hash), resulting in less computational overhead. 

However, itâ€™s important to note that while MD5 is faster, it is considered less secure and more vulnerable to collisions than SHA-512. For applications requiring stronger security, SHA-512 is preferred despite its slower performance.

Selected Answer: C
Agree with what everyone else said. MD5 not the most secure, but faster than SHA-256/512.

Selected Answer: C
Hashing files with MD5, since it's weaker/simpler, will hash faster than SHA256 which will be faster than SHA512. AES is an encryption standard.

questions.question_text: Which of the following enables CSPs to offer unlimited capacity to customers?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
This was in your AZ-900 and your AWS CCP if you took those.

Selected Answer: C
C. Economies of scale

Cloud Service Providers (CSPs) can offer unlimited capacity to customers, in large part, due to economies of scale. Economies of scale refer to the cost advantages that come with increased production or service capacity. As CSPs expand their data centers and infrastructure to serve a global customer base, they can achieve economies of scale by spreading the costs of hardware, data centers, and maintenance across a large number of customers. This allows them to provide seemingly limitless capacity and resources to individual customers without the need for those customers to invest in their own physical infrastructure.

questions.question_text: A company has two primary offices, one in the United States and one in Europe. The company uses a public IaaS service that has a global data center presence to host its marketing materials. The marketing team, which is primarily based in Europe, has reported latency issues when retrieving these materials. Which of the following is the BEST option to reduce the latency issues?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
Explanation:
A Content Delivery Network (CDN) is the best solution for reducing latency when retrieving marketing materials from a globally hosted IaaS platform. CDNs cache and distribute content across multiple edge locations worldwide, ensuring faster access for users in different regions, such as Europe.

comments.content: It's B my bad. I was posting why it wasn't D.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
D. Migrate the applications to a region hosted in Europe:

While moving applications closer to Europe might reduce latency for European users, it could increase latency for U.S.-based users. A CDN is a better, globally optimized solution.

Selected Answer: B
CDN is the best option.

Selected Answer: B
D. CDN

Selected Answer: B
Why D? So you can cause latency issues for the US people? CDN solves for both instead of transferring the problem from one set of users to another. /shrug

Selected Answer: D
D. Migrate the applications to a region hosted in Europe???

comments.content: Has to be CDN. Different locations + Latency = CDN everytime!

choices.D: Migrate the applications to a region hosted in Europe.
choices.B: Integrate a CDN solution to distribute web content globally.
choices.C: Upgrade the bandwidth of the dedicated connection to the IaaS provider.
choices.A: Add an application load balancer to the applications to spread workloads.

choices.D: Enable volume encryption on the storage.
choices.C: Enable protocol encryption between the storage and the hypervisor.
choices.A: Ensure all database queries are encrypted.
choices.B: Create an IPSec tunnel between the database server and its clients.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
Encrypts our data at rest which doesn't touch the VMs, the VM's OSs, but you'd include IPSec for in transit encryption as well. Fairly obvious they want D here though.

Selected Answer: D
Both D and E provide the encryption needed to protect the data, but OS encryption will generally require a pin before it will complete booting = manual intervention.
The solutions don't match the scenario. Maybe someone can enlighten me.

comments.content: Or rather the third sentence in the scenario doesn't seem to match the rest of the scenario.

questions.question_text: A systems administrator is informed that a database server containing PHI and PII is unencrypted. The environment does not support VM encryption, nor does it have a key management system. The server needs to be able to be rebooted for patching without manual intervention. Which of the following will BEST resolve this issue?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
Rendering applications require high graphical processing power, which a GPU passthrough can provide by allowing the virtual desktop to directly access a physical GPU.
This significantly improves rendering speed, screen refresh rate, and overall performance in graphical applications.

comments.content: While increasing memory (Option B) and adding an additional CPU core (Option D) can help with overall system performance, they may not directly address graphics-related issues. Converged infrastructure (Option C) typically refers to the integration of compute, storage, and networking components and might not directly resolve graphics performance issues unless the underlying hardware infrastructure is causing bottlenecks. In this context, enabling GPU passthrough is the most targeted and effective solution.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
The issue described, where a rendering application is running slowly and screen refresh times are long, often points to a need for improved graphics processing capabilities. Therefore, the BEST solution in this scenario is:

A. GPU passthrough

Enabling GPU passthrough allows the virtual desktops to directly access a physical GPU (Graphics Processing Unit). This can significantly improve the performance of graphics-intensive applications like rendering software. With GPU passthrough, the virtual desktops can harness the power of dedicated graphics hardware, resulting in smoother and faster rendering.

Selected Answer: A
By implementing GPU passthrough, the virtual desktops running the rendering application can leverage the full capabilities of the GPU, resulting in improved performance and faster rendering.

Selected Answer: A
Changing my answer to "A". Given the environment, either increasing CPU, memory or GPU resources could improve rendering, but I think CompTia is keeping it basic here and they just want you to know that the GPU is primarily responsible for rendering.

Selected Answer: B
Many online resources (one example below), always list memory as the first thing to check / increase when dealing with rendering issues. 

https://www.crowd-render.com/single-post/rendering-ram-how-does-frequency-number-of-channels-and-capacity-affect-ray-tracing-in-blender

Best answer, in my opinion, is "B".
